text: How do you view all columns of a dataframe? It seems that some solutions pertaining to using show and showall are no longer working.

elements.text: How do you view all columns of a dataframe? It seems that some solutions pertaining to using show and showall are no longer working.

text: use FloatingTableView.jl, I don't think there is a good solution in the REPL

elements.text: use FloatingTableView.jl, I don't think there is a good solution in the REPL

text: <@UBF9YRB6H> Thanks, this looks beautiful and very easy to use.

elements.text: Thanks, this looks beautiful and very easy to use.

text: <@UBF9YRB6H> This opened up a huge dataframe blazing fast! I didn't even see my memory or cpu affected.  How's this even possible?

elements.text: This opened up a huge dataframe blazing fast! I didn't even see my memory or cpu affected.  How's this even possible?

text: It does lazy loading. I know very little about the implementation, since it's just a wrapper for TableView.jl. But i'm glad it works!

elements.text: It does lazy loading. I know very little about the implementation, since it's just a wrapper for TableView.jl. But i'm glad it works!

text: ooh nice, I should use this sometimes

elements.text: ooh nice, I should use this sometimes

text: maybe I can combine it with my I3.jl package to make nice table viewing in I3 that manages windows in a really nice way

elements.text: maybe I can combine it with my I3.jl package to make nice table viewing in I3 that manages windows in a really nice way

text:
<@UBF9YRB6H> yeah it works wonderfully.  I had initially used describe(df) to know which columns had missng values but I was only manage to see a few of the columns at a time in the REPL.
I was able to do some forward filling with a package called Impute.jl but since their is no value before the headers, I also backfilled the columns with missing headers. FloatingTableView.jl helped me spot all the columns with missing header values fast.

elements.text:
yeah it works wonderfully.  I had initially used describe(df) to know which columns had missng values but I was only manage to see a few of the columns at a time in the REPL.
I was able to do some forward filling with a package called Impute.jl but since their is no value before the headers, I also backfilled the columns with missing headers. FloatingTableView.jl helped me spot all the columns with missing header values fast.

text: Fwiw I still think jupyter Notebooks are most comfortable for explorative coding with data, with Atom/Juno (together with the TableView package) coming second

elements.text: Fwiw I still think jupyter Notebooks are most comfortable for explorative coding with data, with Atom/Juno (together with the TableView package) coming second

text: Really cool. Though you can also use `show(df, allrows=true, allcols=true)` if you want to print everything.

elements.text: Really cool. Though you can also use
if you want to print everything.

text:
> maybe I can combine it with my I3.jl package to make nice table viewing in I3 that manages windows in a really nice way
I actually downloaded QT creator today. They have a *really* fast lazy built-in table viewer. I think that Stata probably upstreamed their table viewer and we can reap the benefits. Would be a long term project though, but would work nicer with i3
